Problem:
Consider a system governed by the partial differential equation \\(u_t + u_{xx} = 0\\), where \\(u_t\\) and \\(u_{xx}\\) are the time and second space derivatives of \\(u\\), respectively. To study the problem, we use the Fourier transform \\(\\hat{u}(k, t) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} e^{-ikx} u(x,t)dx\\).

If at a time \\(t_1\\), an intervention applies an inverse Fourier transform followed by a function modification \\(\\tilde{u}(x, t_1) = u(x, t_1) + c\\) (where c is a constant) and then is transformed again, will the end value of \\(\\hat{u}(k, T)\\) for \\(T > t_1\\) depend solely on the initial conditions at \\(t = 0\\)?
Explanation: The intervention alters the state of the system at time \\(t_1\\) by modifying the spatial function \\(u(x, t_1)\\). This change directly affects the subsequent evolution of the system and the Fourier transform at any time \\(T > t_1\\). Consequently, \\(\\hat{u}(k, T)\\) at time \\(T\\) depends on both the initial conditions and the changes made during the intervention.

causal_map_integration: The time derivative of u influences the value of u, which in turn affects its second space derivative. The function u is transformed into its Fourier representation, hat(u), which is modified at time t1 into tilde(u) by adding a constant c. This modified function tilde(u) is then transformed back into Fourier space, influencing the value of hat(u) at time t1. Finally, hat(u) at time t1 affects hat(u) at a later time T.
